Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Community-Driven Precision GPS Service
Award.AbstractNarration:
The high cost and technical complexity of current precision positioning solutions make them inaccessible to a large market segment that would be otherwise inclined to use such solutions. Some examples of these potential market applications include the tracking of extreme sport activities, precision agriculture, intelligent transportation, navigation of unmanned vehicles, such as UAVs, robots, personal drones,as well as sensor data collection for use in academia and by government agencies, or even do-it-yourself land surveying. Customers in these markets must currently make do with the decreased accuracies available to them given their budgetary constraints, or they must pay exorbitant prices for custom hardware solutions. The proposed will bridge the gap between cost and accuracy and capture the market share of independent developers and small businesses that either do not have the time, the resources, or the money to spend on existing solutions.

This team proposes to build a precision absolute positioning service. The proposed innovation introduces a network of stationary receivers at known locations, such that the position relative to any one of these stationary nodes will result in coordinates in an absolute geodetic coordinate space. Additionally, this team proposes to carry out the localization procedure in a cloud-based infrastructure which will enable performing much more computationally complex operations as well as fuse data across multiple sensors to increase the accuracy of the system even further. We believe this always-on, always-ready cloud-based positioning platform will nicely abstract away most of the major problems that developers needing precision location information currently face. The levels of accuracy achievable by the proposed system are sufficient for many applications, and although the proposed solution currently relies on relative localization results, the placement of a few receivers at well-known locations would open the door for an absolute localization service that could run in the cloud.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The accuracy of consumer-grade GPS-based localization is in the range of several meters. For many applications, including drone navigation, autonomous driving, and tracking of sports activities like skiing, off-road biking, car racing, etc., better accuracy is required. Existing techniques such as Differential GPS or Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) navigation are typically expensive and have various disadvantages including long setup and calibration times and a reliance on one or more "reference nodes" for operation. Under a previous National Science Foundation (NSF) Networking Technology and Systems (NeTS) grant, we developed a novel, high-accuracy, GPS-based relative positioning technique with the aim of overcoming some of the limitations imposed by existing methodologies at a reasonable price. Under the NSF I-Corps program, we explored the commercial viability of extending our technique by utilizing one or more base stations at well-known locations; thus, the relative locations reported by our system with respect to a known point may be translated into absolute locations. After interviewing over one hundred potential customers, we found that there is significant interest in multiple customer segments for a more accurate localization service than traditional GPS but at non-prohibitive prices. As one of our interviewees stated: "accuracy is addictive." On the other hand, we also found that the majority of would-be customers require a service that works in historically "difficult" GPS environments, (i.e., under dense foliage or in urban canyons). Therefore, our conclusion is that we have identified a clear need in multiple market segments for our technology, but additional research is needed to make it more robust and reliable. We are currently working to address these expressed needs and have several customers already in the pipeline awaiting a beta version of our commercial prototype. Thanks to the I-Corps program, we have a much better understanding of the process required to achieve entrepreneurial success, and we fully intend to continue pursuing commercialization of our technology which, we believe, has the potential to disrupt the market and have a far-reaching impact on location-enabled applications in the future.
